comments.comment_body: Except it's not a "Craze."  It's based on Israel's persecution of the Palestinian people.  And for me, it has absolutely nothing to do with the Jewish religion. It's nothing but cruel and it's been going on for way too long.  And Netanyahu has absolutely no intention of changing anything.  They were supposed to be negotiating over land that Israel had occupied. But how do the Palestinians negotiate for land that is slowly being swallowed up by Israeli settlements. The Israelis have never been serious about giving the Palestinians their own homeland.  That is extremely obvious by now.

Nonsense. Opposing the brutalization of the Palestinian people does not equate to anti-semitism.

I hold the radical position that Jews and Muslims alike should refrain from blowing each other up/ bulldozing homes, etc. what a concept!
The irony is that a certain percentage of anti-Israel students can't wait to signup for "Birthright Israel"--a  program that gives them a free trip to the country they disdain.

Mearsheimer & Walt book. Israel Lobby.  Definitive.  Local rabbis equated it with Protocols of the Elders of Zion to prevent the congregation from reading it or accepting anything in it.  Mearsheimer and Walt should have gotten Nobel Peace Prize.    'nuff said.

Much of what Israeli leadership and its water carriers have said over the last half century about inept and corrupt Palestinian leadership has been true.  Which tells us a lot about Israeli leadership which has lost the global PR battle over that period.

Nonsense. This is America. Not Israel. Everyone has the freedom of speech to question whether it is in their interest or the American interest to be so closely identified with a state which does not preach or practice equality for all its citizens. When Israel stops the close to 60 year occupation and stops brutalizing Palestinians then perhaps some criticism will abate.

But trying to equate criticism of Israel with hatred of Jews is akin to equating criticism of apartheid South Africa with hatred of white people. It's thoroughly dishonest. 

And more people are seeing through it which is probably why there are more and more attacks on BDS and the ability to criticize Israel.

The call by the rabbis for people to be ultra-vigilant about any "ism" in their own ideological homes is particularly well-taken. This is particularly true when it comes to the left and antisemitism. Right wing antisemitism is easy to pick out; it isn't that hard for the FBI etc. to infiltrate their web of crazies. Islamist antisemitism is not so hard to pick out, either. when imams spout it from the pulpit and it is expressed on the Arab street. African-American and Latinx antisemitism is harder to call out, because of the natural leftist inclination to justify it, make excuses for it, and disinclination to call out POC for anything that might put their leftist votes at risk. General leftist antisemitism is hardest of all, because of how pervasive it is in the academy, and because many left-of-center Zionists have learned to keep their heads down and mouths shut lest their careers and futures be wrecked. But make no mistake. Calling for the end of Israel as a Jewish state is as antisemitic as calling for the end of Sweden as a Swedish state is anti-Swedish, and it doesn't help to profess love for the Swedes and/or the Jews.

As a Palestinian-American whose father and grandparents were driven from Haifa in 1948, this is an emotional issue for me. 

When I read in this piece that someone had implored children to be “freedom fighters” against Israel, my first thought was, “Good.” Then I took a moment to calm down and think, and I thought about what it means to indoctrinate children, who don’t understand the differences between states and people. But a lot of adults can’t, either, including, I would argue, the authors of this piece, who conflate anti-Zionism with antisemitism. I grew up thinking Zionism was racist; I still do. But it does not compare to the unrivaled horror of Nazism, and conflating the two is wrong. 

My father is now an American citizen, and a registered Democrat. He would never admit it, but he hates the Jews. He also hates Israel. It is the hatred for the same thing: He can’t seem to help conflating the two. It is as if the trauma of 1948, which he endured around age five, has glued everything together into one blazing ball of hatred. If you listen to his story, and hear about my grandmother being shot at, and about leaving in the middle of the night with tank blasts coming from the north, maybe you can understand the feeling—even if the sentiment is racist. Antisemitic. 

When commentators and others propose their solutions, these are some of the things I think about.

"Students reported that while we were speaking, the teacher flipped a middle finger at one of us."

That's quite polite compared to what has happened at other schools when people disapproved of a speaker.

Anyway, the authors fail to say whether the format allowed audience members to ask questions or to rebut the speakers AT THE TIME.

The Palestinian project is near collapse today, internally and externally, economically and politically. The West Bank and Gaza are fiefdoms of graft, bribery and corruption, utterly dependent today for their basic needs on the kindness of strangers and Israel.

For 70 years now, the Palestinians  -- with relatively little help from Israel -- have rendered their own cause illegitimate by waging permanent war and terror against their legitimate neighbor; and by resisting all efforts by Israel to normalize its presence in the Middle East. 

I hope the good Rabbis who are now out in these schools seeking 
tolerance and understanding for Jews and Israel had the presence 
of mind to inform these kids that Palestinians are bereft of elections today because of the actions of their leaders.

The authors write: “To describe Zionism as racism, to deny Israel’s most basic right to exist, is anti-Semitic in effect, if not in intent. Why is Israel the only country in the world whose right to exist is not just questioned but actively campaigned against? Israel’s enemies protest that they are simply anti-Zionist, not anti-Semitic, yet their view of justice requires eliminating the one and only Jewish state.”

I’m Jewish. Are they really so obtuse? All you have to do is look at the history of the founding of Israel, the displacements, the grabs, which even today over 75 years later are not considered helpful or legitimate! It’s the history — those who wanted to lay claim or refused to when given the opportunity back in the 1940s obviously consider Israel illegitimate! I support their right to exist but it is no mystery whatever as to why some do not, and why it is a unique situation in the world as such due to the facts of their founding. The rabbis need to retire a very stale argument and look at other root causes — they do some of this.

Zionism is an extremely racist idea.  Labeling anti-Zionists, a group that includes many Jews, as antisemitic is very problematic.  Stop diluting the definition if antisemitism down to mean essentially nothing and encompass everything!
When will people begin to understand that anti-Israel is not anti-Jew? Being critical of a country's government is not anti-Semitism.

Trump and his white supremacist fans are not the only reason for the the Anti Israel craze. The other main reason is Benjamin Netanyahu, who has, with his hard line attitude and intransigence, made Israel seem quite the bully. Even with Israel's many good reasons to be tough, it doesn't have to be cruel. 

There is a difference.

"To describe Zionism as racism, to deny Israel’s most basic right to exist, is anti-Semitic in effect, if not in intent. Why is Israel the only country in the world whose right to exist is not just questioned but actively campaigned against?"

Israel, in fact, does not have a right to exist as a Jewish-first state. Why should it? Jewish-Israelis have a right to live in peace with their Arab-Israeli neighbors and to share equal rights with them, that's it. 

Only Zionists fail to understand what an abomination Israel is in its present form, and how unavoidable is the oppression of the Palestinian people as a result.

To me personally the treatment of the Palestinians by the state of Israel with the active collusion of the Trump administration is a horrendous injustice. Deliberately, Israel wants to eventually occupy the entire West Bank and that is an intolerable injustice. As it is now the Palestinians are living in a ghetto created by the State of Israel and little by little, new settlement by new settlement on Palestinian land their right to exist as an independent people is being destroyed. There is nothing else to be said.b

I have read and reread the account of what happened in the November assembly:
Mr. Ahmed said, “I use the same example in talking about the Holocaust. That Jews who suffered in the Holocaust and established the State of Israel today, they perpetuate violence against Palestinians.”
I still don't see how Jews are being equated with Nazis. What I see is a statement about how a State established by members of a group that endured extreme injustice and violence, is now behaving violently towards another group. This has nothing to do with hating Jews or some "Anti-Israel Craze" or fad. It is an observation about how a history of being victimized does not preclude victimizing others. That we must never forget to look in the mirror. This is not about Jews, it is an observation about human nature.

Where are the Divest from China movements?  The Chinese have been occupying Tibet since 1950.  Where is the international outrage?  Why are college students not demanding that their universities stop investing in all Chinese companies?  Oh wait, the Chinese aren't Jewish.

The remarkable thing is the complete unaccountability  held for  the Palestinian leaders and their constituency.

For one thing the land we are talking about is miniscule.  Israel is 263 miles long and 71 miles wide at its narrowest point. About the size of NJ.

Yet, the Palestinians have the highest population growth as a percentage of its population in the world. There are in fact more Palestinians living in Israel proper than any time in history. 
The Palestinian also comprise a majority of the population in Jordan.

The Palestinians who live in Israel have better lives and more rights than Palestians in most of the world. Where are all the Jews who were living in the Arab lands? … answer Fled to Israel to save thier lives. 

At the start of WWII there were about 6 million Jews living in Europe, at the end of it about 100 thousand. That is genocide.
Today there are 10x as many Palestinians as there were at the inception of Israel; that's where population growth takes you if your only goal is to get rid of the Jewish people, rather than building a better life for yourself and your people .
Anti-Israel 'craze'? We are anti Israeli Government. Not anti Israeli People.

I am puzzled as to why we, as Americans, have focused so much of our attention on Israel.  If we were looking at our relationship with other nations, why would it not be Saudi Arabia and our obscene partnership with that country over the years?  How many wars and how much widespread misery, has our desire for oil caused?  Is 9/11 so easily forgotten?  
 Israel, for all its many faults, has a vibrant press, open and forthright debates about Palestine and Israel, and is certainly at the forefront of women's rights in the Middle East.
As an onlooker, boycotting and divesting from Halliburton and Aramco would seem to make the most sense.  Yes?  No?

What would the authors say to a stance (essentially the one-state solution position) that asserted that Israel absolutely has the right to exist, but only as a country that offers equal democratic rights to all its citizens (and that all people living within the territories it controls must be considered citizens)? This "one-democratic-state solution" was essentially the solution applied in South Africa, a country with its origins as a settler colony that eventually had to grant citizenship to all its people and uphold equal rights for all. This did not lead to South African whites being driven from the country, nor to their ability to live with dignity and rights intact within its borders. This one-state solution does *not* oppose Israel's right to exist; it only suggests that it must offer democratic rights of citizenship to all within the borders of the territories it chooses to exercise control over.

I am Jewish. I believe in democracy, and the idea that all citizens of a country should be on an equal footing, rather than prioritizing one ethnic group. For that reason, I think that having a Jewish state is wrong. This makes me anti-Zionist.

I don’t expect everyone to agree with me, but I think I am entitled to demand to not be called anti-Semitic. This charge is being dishonestly used, in order to shout down opinions to which the authors are opposed. 

I live near the Fieldston School, and was aware of the controversy. I have no opinion as to whether an obscene gesture at a contentious meeting is sufficient cause to fire a teacher, but I suspect that the firing, as well as calling people like me anti-Semitic, and also the laws to try to stamp out the BDS movement, are all designed to silence legitimate expression, in order to disguise on what shaky moral ground ethno-nationalism rests on in the 21st century.

There is a difference between criticizing the prime minister of Israel and criticizing Israeli policies generally.

There is also a difference between taking issue with some Israeli policies and taking issue with the people of Israeli (many of whom criticize both the current prime minister and his policies).

There is also a difference between all of that and anti-Semitism.

To fight anti-Semitism, it is not helpful to carelessly allege it by conflating it with opposition to some politicians in Israel. Especially, when real anti-Semitism is on the rise, as it quite unfortunately and quite certainly is.

After minoring in The Study of Genocide in the early 1980s and knowing the reality of anti-Semitism directed at me and my cohorts in my university's Jewish Student Union, I knew anti-Semitism would not vanish; however, I did not believe it would metastasize in the body of humanity as is evidenced by the virulent anti-Semitism noted in this op-ed and in society at-large. My fear is that it will become worse; not better.

It is the intensity of hatred and moral selectivity that makes so much of the anti-Israel movement antisemitic.  Israel as a human rights violator but not Syria or Hamas?  Israel as religious nationalism but not Saudia Arabia or even ISIS?

But the authors take this just a little too far.  Hungary, to take one example, is a country with policies explicitly aimed at ensuring a Hungarian ethnic nation-state. I oppose these Hungarian policies, and it could be validly said I oppose Hungarian nationalism.

Israel is already a more ethnically diverse nation than Hungary, but the same principle holds.  It is possible to be opposed to ethnic-based nationalism and NOT be anti-semitic.  But people need to be consistent.

Enough with the thin-skinned obfuscation. The Israeli government and its brutal treatment of Palestine does NOT represent Judaism. It is perfectly acceptable to criticize a government. In fact, that's the only way to keep it in check. It is NOT antisemitic to support fair and equal treatment of fellow humans. 

It's amazing that the authours of this article characterize criticism of Israel as "primal loathing" -- they seem genuinely shocked that someone could have problems with a manifest destiny mindset. Yet they fail to mention that Israeli policies have been bulldozing, shooting, disappearing and killing Palestinians for decades. 

Neither side is innocent, obviously. But undeniably there is a lopsided power relationship between the 2 nations. Both have a right to exist and flourish. For that to happen, Israel needs to remove its boot from Palestine's throat, to step out of the bubble of Israel-at-all-costs and into the greater world of the human family.

I think that the reality is that some Jewish Americans (like the writers of this Op-Ed and perhaps some of the Fieldston parents in their congregations) reflexively support Israel as a matter of identity and, literally, faith, and conflate criticism of Israel as an ethnic state as anti-semitic, and, regardless of facts, accept only limited criticism of Israeli policies toward the Palestinians.  (My own view is that this is mistaken and unfortunate, and, in some cases, disingenuous).

What we need maybe is a Baptist state somewhere and a Presbyterian state maybe somewhere else.  An agnostic state would be good too.

  Religious states are a real hindrance to peace.  We all know that there is but one divine force.  Arguing about the correct way to approach it is very silly and basing a government on this is grotesque.

I currently attend the Fieldston school, as well as the synagogue of one of the authors of this article. I have a first-hand experience of the teacher, the rabbis, and the school currently being addressed in the numerous articles that have been published. Having witnessed this whole conflict as a student, I would first like to make it clear that silencing any opinion, including opinions that feel immoral and wrong, constricts education. To silence opinions curbs students' ability to make their own judgments and suggests that students cannot determine right from wrong. When schools begin to censor what ideas their students are exposed to, progress, as well as our education, is stunted. When the rabbis write, 'it is our diversity that strengthens society' does this not include the diversity of opinion? 

The teacher in question was always welcoming of students in every learning environment. The students' opinions and ideas were always respected. Likewise, the teacher's perspective was always appreciated by their students even when we disagreed. 

I do not feel in any way that I have been taught to demonize Israel through my school or my teachers nor do I feel that any of the faculty at Fieldston have vilified Israel's right to exist. In fact, through the diversity of opinions I have been exposed to in my education, I have been able to find and honor my Jewish identity.

You miss the whole point.  Most criticism of Israel is grounded in the denial of its right to exist.  It’s too late to question Zionism - Israel rightfully exists.  Just like it’s too late to protest against the 4th of July, but claim to have no problem with the basic concept of the United States of America.
The same folks that constantly question Israel - a flawed, but true democracy with freedoms of press, religion and speech - are the same folks that could care less about criticizing countries without ANY of such freedoms.  Wake up - it’s anti-semitism!

I am a holocaust survivor, (second hand), my ancestors were wiped out by Nazis, and I say from first hand experience that Zionism is a racist movement, that Israel is a racist state, and that the land on which it sits was stolen from people who had lived there for thousands of years. My father, whose father died at Auschwitz, and who lived in Palestine from 1946-1950 believed exactly these same things. I am unequivocal in my condemnation of everything that the Zionist state represents. Right to exist? No, people have a right to exist; nations must earn that right.
So, tell your leader to quit bombing innocent Palestinians and I'll be supportive. Israel has indeed acted like their oppressors in the treatment of those people, and you know it.

It's simple. Israel pulls out of the West Bank, stops the siege and bombing of Gaza, stops discriminating against non-Jews in Israel, and begins to honestly coexist with its neighbors.  Then most people won't have an issue with Israel. Right now, people are tired of its incessant bullying.

Maybe these two authors should try listening instead of talking? 

They may find that people can be critical of Israel w/out being "anti-semitic", a term that is now being used to effectively shut people up or stop them from voicing their views. 

Just look at the school's firing of a teacher who wanted to discuss Israel's horrible treatment of Palestine. And the Trump Administration's attack on free speech re: Israel on college campuses. I'd love to see their outrage about that.

Hinduism is the oldest religion in the world. Ancient Hindu kingdoms extended all the way to Kandahar (Sanskrit name: Gandhar) in present day Afghanistan. If the Hindus of India invaded Pakistan and Afghanistan using that ancient history as an excuse would that be acceptable to the world?
Was it acceptable to the world for Iraq to invade Kuwait using past history as an excuse? 
Why then is it important for the world to quietly accept Israel's right to exist in the Middle East simply based on past religious history?

I agree that hatred of Jews and Israel is senseless and barbaric, and that hate speech and hateful actions towards Jews is evil.

However, the authors must be careful to not mix morality and politics, which is exactly what they seem to be leaning towards here.

So people are not allowed to criticize Israel's government and its policies, nor criticize its military actions, nor its treatment of Palestinians? Such criticism does not necessarily fall into the category of 'a hateful obsession with Israel (that) too often descends into hatred of Jews' - - it all depends on context and the actual wording of remarks.

People around the world see fit to eviscerate America, Americans, and all they both stand for, and no one says that perceived hatred of Americans is some moral failure.

Attacks and hate speech against Jews and Israel? Never. Israel being held accountable for its actions, being validly criticized for its attitudes, policies, government, just like every other world power? Of course.
This is an important contribution from the political left/ non-Orthodox rabbis.

I wish to isolate one element of this complex and contentious situation that I think is fostering anti-Israeli sentiment and anti-Semitism in a particularly misleading and cruel way. That is, the current disciplinary trend which "reads" the Israel/Palestine conflict through the lens of settler colonialism. My opinion doesn't mean that I would give Israel a "pass." Nor does it mean that I think that settler colonialism is without merit as a theoretical perspective. However, the use of this perspective in education has fostered facile and uncritical comparisons between the the destruction of indigenous peoples worldwide, American slavery, and the creation of Israel a nation. Not to mention the comparison between Israel and the Holocaust cited in this current article -- comparison that is beyond ugly. See for example: https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/13/world/middleeast/professors-angry-tweets-on-gaza-cost-him-a-job.html

In order for the country of Israel to be created,700,000 Palestinians had to be removed. The rights of these people was a issue in 1948 and is still today. To search for an equitable solution for the sins of past Zionists is not anti Israel.

Regardless of your feelings about how the current Israeli government is treating Palestinians (and there has been plenty of violence going both ways over the past 100 years) . . . 

Denying the right of Jews to a homeland is anti-semitic. 

At least 60 countries are identified as Muslim or Christian, according to a 2005 Harvard study, and indeed, a future Palestine, would be Islamic governed by Sharia law per the proposed Basic Laws adopted by the Palestinian Legislative Council (2003).

Aren’t Jews entitled to one country?

Can’t they have one small piece of land where the official language is Hebrew, the Jewish holidays are national holidays and Jews are guaranteed citizenship?

As a father of Jewish children and wife and as someone who has for several decades materially supported Israeli institutions financially, I find the rise in antisemitism troubling, to say the least.  However, the underlying message in this article is that Israel is exempt from criticism and scrutiny and any criticism is de facto antisemitism.  These author's words make clear that blind support of the government and state of Israel is a requirement of being pro-Jewish.  The authors react to combustible comparisons between actions by Israel against Pallestinians and those of Nazis.  Ths is simply misdirection.   Shutting down debate, policing the language of critics & using broad accusations of antisemtism do not make people more tolerant of Jewish people or more supportive of the policies of Israel. Israeli policies concerning the West Bank, Settlements, & Gaza, deserve real scrutiny

I'm curious who wrote the headline. I ask because 'craze' seems a bit of an exaggeration. Since 2015, twenty-seven states have outlawed BDS movements or enacted bans on companies that have ties to BDS movements. And just recently, President Trump declared that Jewishness was a nationality not a religion and, therefore, entitled to legal protections. 

But, of course, declaring someone's point of view and actions illegal won't at all increase resentment, encourage some to try harder and others to become bitter, possibly violent. Just ask the Palestinians.

Tying the founding of Israel as a antidote to the Holocaust is only partially true. Theodore Herzl in his Zionist writings in England and the philantropists Rothschilds established farms on land in Palestine owned by that family in the early 1900s and 1920s. Jews lived with Arabs for millenia in Palestine and even stayed at the same King David hotel. I know for a fact that Ben Gurion a leader and underground fighter against the British protectorate visited many  displaced persons  camps in Munich and elsewhere around 1945-46. After exhorting    the fraction of  young adult survivors in the US zone, he urged them to immigrate to Palestine. Some Jews  took him up on his offer. Others like my parents didn't and resettled in Europe, the US or South America to start their lives from scratch. Zionism predates the  Holocaust and while Palestine was still under British control.

There are 22 Arab countries.  The land they rule is larger than the United States.  There is one Jewish country, it is smaller than New Jersey.  The Kurds, The Copts, The Yazidis are all denied countries by the Arabs who came out of Arabia and conquered the region.  If I were to say that the Arabs should return to Arabia from where they came, there would be a firestorm, but that is equivalent of telling Jews to leave their historical homeland and go elsewhere.   

22 Arab countries, 99+% of the land in the middle east.  Seems like enough room for all of the Arabs, including the distant descendants of the refugees who fled the Arabs' failed 1948 and 1967 genocidal wars against the Jews.

That it is theoretically possible to criticize Israel without being an anti-Semite has unfortunately just given cover to anti-Semites who criticize Israel.  There are about 175 imperfect countries with some 7 billion people in the world.  Why is it that there is so much criticism of a tiny country with a few million people?

Jewish-Americans are unfairly burdened by association with the state of Israel. Christian-Americans are not similarly burdened by association with an independent Christian nation.

Isn't that reason enough to judge all hyphenated Americans by their achievements, not by the behavior of some foreign country?

Israel unilaterally declared 50% of Palestine to be Israel.

It was about 2/3 Arab and 1/3 Jewish.

After the 1948 war and Palestinians fleeing, it was probably 60% Jewish and 40% Arab.

Today it is around 80% Jewish and 20% Arab.

And a refugee born in Haifa in 1943, whose parents took him across the border to Lebanon for safety in 1948 until the war was over, is not allowed to return to Haifa, where he was born, where his family owned land and a home, where his roots go back hundreds of years.

But a Jew anywhere in the world can be a citizen of Israel.

The Jews want their homeland.

He would like to return to his homeland, too.

Antisemitism manifests itself in many forms. Israel is the only democracy in the area. The Jews have been subject to violent attacks and are in area surrounded by its enemies. Few are acquainted with its history and its necessity as a haven for persecuteJews. Israel is the only country subject to such hostile and unremitting scrutiny. It is clear that such attacks by the left are in part at least motivated by antisemitism. Hatred of China, Russia Turkey, North Korea does not permeate our society. Only Israel! The Jews have the right to self determination as any other people. I see no groundswell of concern for the Kurds who were denied a country under the Versailles treaty and have been subjected to persecution by Turkey, Iraq, Syria and Iran. Iran a country whichis both despotic and who I
kills  it’s own people, threatens its neighbors, finances terrorists is not subject to such scrutiny. Thancient hatred of the Jews is manifesting itself on the left by attacking the Jewish state and Jews in this country. We are witnessing the enormous rise of Jewish hate crimes.

I wish the writer well; however, he's swimming on contradictions.
There _was no_ 'left' in Europe "for centuries," so it would have had a hard time being anti-Semitic...a  phrase invented at the turn of the 20th century. In mid-century, Stalinism in E. and Central Europe was de-facto anti-Semitic. Many would challenge the label "leftwing" for the despots of Soviet Russia. Later, in the 1980s, a fringe of the Western 'left' became frank anti-Semites, and that is true. 
I could go on, but bandwidth wanes. Just one thing. "Why is Israel," asks the writer, "the only country in the world whose right to exist is not just questioned but actively campaigned against?" Actually, virtually every colonial state set up anywhere in the world has been challenged and fought against. And, at its origin, Israel was a colonial construct. It would be so healing to admit that.
 Then, Boer South Africa and Rhodesia and the Ottoman Empire, and later, the Nazi puppet regime of central and western Europe... all were challenged and fought against. Ask yourself why before crying 'wolf'.
I'm Jewish and I loathe what Israel is doing to the Palestines. We have become the bullies we fought against. So I guess this makes me anti-Semitic?
Who represents the views of Palestinians living in Gaza or the West Bank under the boot if israeli IDF forces?

There's another side to this story that the authors ignore. The federal government is trying to make it illegal to criticize Israel's policies in the occupied West Bank by, for example, advocating for the BDS (Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions) movement. BDS is directed against Israel's illegal settlements in the West Bank. For a detailed discussion see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel_Anti-Boycott_Act People are losing their jobs if they don't sign away their freedom of speech and promise they will never be an advocate for this movement. Some state governments are threatening to cut off funding to schools where the "boycott" is even mentioned on campus. The authors would find that most BDS supporters are against the rising anti-Semitic attacks in schools, temples, and everywhere else. Unfortunately, the authors' definition of Semites will probably never include the Palestinians.

The problem that has to be squarely comprehended and addressed is that Israel's existence is predicated on legalized vanquishing of people from their own land from afar, and by countries that denied Jews a homeland within their borders. The leading governments of the world simply didn't want anything to do with Jews and sought to plop them somewhere that won't pose them any problems - enter Palestine. The fact that Israel was gifted land belonging to others should be at least humbling for Israeli's, but it appears to inexplicably be the opposite. They seem emboldened to advocate for and act aggressively, and stubbornly, against any semblance for peace by land-grabbing more land that doesn't belong to them. I know many vociferously disagree and would be quick to pick up a Bible to prove Israel belongs to Israeli's. But if we were to re-draw land boundaries and repopulate native people back from whence the Bible said they came, there would be many more folks advocating for a non-biblical way.

I would like, for a moment, to reframe this issue in a different fashion in order to clarify something that is being obfuscated by the authors of this piece.  I see no contradiction between defending Christians from discrimination, persecution, and violent attacks and at the same time opposing a government that reserves superior rights to Christians while discriminating against, persecuting, and violently attacking non-Christians.  While some people who oppose Christian supremacy might do so because they hate Christians I think most people would be able to distinguish between opposing a Christian supremacist government and hating Christians.  I can't speak for every anti-Zionist or critic of the policies of the Israeli government towards Palestinians under it's control, but I can say that I wholeheartedly support defending Jews wherever they may live from discrimination and violent attack by anti-Semites while at the same time I oppose Zionism because it is in practice a policy of Jewish supremacy over and ethnic cleansing of non-Jews in the state of Israel.  That is the history of the Zionist colonization of Palestine and continues to this day, and to my mind is by any standards of democracy and equality indefensible.

This is such an old and tired argument: support for Palestine=anti-semitism. Israel is just like any other country that should be judged not by what it says and purports to be but what rather what it does.

Much of the anti-Israel position today stems from the fact that  the criminal PM -- Netanyahu and his Likkud Party -- have turned Israel away from the former position of trying to achieve a two-state solution.  Netanyahu also supports the racist, bigot Donald Trump and when Obama was the president attempted to undermine and humiliate him by doing an end around with Congress so he could be invited to speak to them as though he had any reason to be there or anything useful to say.   
As long as Israel's policy is to humiliate and demean the Palestinians and encroach on their land with "settlements," the nation of Israel will feel scorn.   That is not anti-Semitism -- that is disliking the destructive, regressive policies of another country.   We aren't anti-Iranian or anti-Korean or anti-Russian just because we dislike their oppressive, ugly government policies.   It's the same with the Jewish people -- it's not the people, it's their government that we disdain.

Why are these writers trying to argue that staunch criticism of a sovereign state should be equated with either hatred of Israel or hatred of the Jews? Teaching students to think critically means empowering them to state publicly when they think something is wrong.

There are plenty of people (Jews and Gentiles alike) who have the independence of mind to decide for themselves when Israeli politicians are acting unethically. Let's grant them the right to reach those conclusions on their own.

It’s indeed shocking that Israel, and not Yemen, Syria, Venezuela (the list goes on and on) remains a focal point for defenders of “human rights”, including the educated left. If not fueled by anti-Semitism, then how else can we explain this misplaced attention?

Is it possible that some of the liberal high school student hatred of Israel is the perception that Israel is pro Trump? Netanyahu certainly has made his preferences known, and he was exceptionally rude to Barack Obama.  I am not sure that the average student is that well versed in the Palestinian conflict.

Granted Israel is not as bad as some other countries especially in that neighborhood but none of these other countries get billions every year from the US or has nuclear capacity. The premise on which this essay is based -- that illegal immigration depresses the incomes of legal residents -- is a contested one. Economists have examined the question and come to diametrically opposed conclusions, in many cases because of the assumptions on which their studies were based, or their extrapolation of particular populations to the US as a whole, or changes to both immigration and the workforce over several decades. In 2017, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine examined the question [https://www.nap.edu/read/23550/chapter/2] and found little evidence that immigration significantly affects the overall employment levels of native-born workers, and that overall the inflow of foreign-born workers was a relatively minor factor in the $18 trillion US economy. Where immigration was significant was in reducing hours worked by US teenagers and prior immigrants. Nevertheless, I don't dispute that immigration reform is long overdue. In 2005, John McCain and Ted Kennedy sponsored a bipartisan reform bill that included a pathway to citizenship; it failed in the Republican majority Senate. Eight years later, in 2013, McCain was part of the 'Gang of Eight' that helped pass the Border Security, Economic Opportunity and Immigration Modernization Act; it passed the Democratic majority Senate 68-32 but the Republican House refused to bring it up for a vote. It's clear that the obstacle to sane policy is not Democrats, but Republicans.

There are some additional factors. First is the history of legalizing immigration: in the 19th century we started with no system and then passed racist legislation excluding Chinese immigrants -- excluding them as potential citizens, that is. Comprehensive immigration reform really waited for the racist 1924 Immigration Act -- embracing the quota system (people admitted by national origin based on fractions of a previous US population's national origin, racial exclusion of Asians) and dooming people from large parts of the world to exclusion or excruciating delay. Further reforms in 1965 and 1986 didn't eliminate the preferences. The other big factor is the history of our southern-southwestern border: the US started as an English settlers' republic on the eastern seaboard with a tense relationship to indigenous and enslaved people, but we rapidly expanded into territory that included new groups of natives as well as Spanish-speaking settlers. It's not so much that Latinx immigrants moved into the US as that the US moved into Latin America. The artificiality of the border we're trying to fortify is most obvious where there's no visible geographic feature defining it, though it's worth mentioning that even the Rio Grande isn't a real natural dividing line, and there was a time when the Nueces was the legal line even for Texas.

The competitive exploitation model is of mutual benefit to all parties involved, and it is the failure of the source countries (e.g. Indonesia on the low end and India on the high end) that gives Singapore this opportunity.

It is always disheartening to hear people say that they wouldn’t vote for this or that female politician because she i.e. Warren , Clinton etc. reminded them too much of that no-nonsense, demanding junior/high school teacher that they didn’t like and who apparently (through no fault of their own of course) didn’t give them the classroom recognition they felt they deserved. Now, as an adult I am able to look back on those teachers with respect for the knowledge and disciplined thinking they worked so hard to  try to instill in us- fairly, and often against the odds. 

Now more than ever, we need a president who is knowledgeable, dedicated, serious, cares about everyone in the American “classroom” and is determined to make their lives better. Elizabeth Warren ticks all those boxes for me “school marmish” or not.

Yes, let's ponder how Hillary came up short by ~77,000 votes in 3 states, thus losing the electoral college and giving Trump the Presidency. Some of us remember reports of hacking of social media and dirty tricks to keep voters from voting. 77,000 isn't much of a margin.
We haven't protected ourselves against those very much.  Or other things that could explain the 77,000.

If we're talking about women, let's talk about mail ballots and men, especially men who like Strong Men candidates. (Remember Alex Jones secretly voting  his estranged wife's mail ballot?)  Mail ballots make voter coercion within the household if Big Daddy or Big Brother rule. The 'secret' in 'secret ballot' can be hard to keep. Compare voting in a booth at a public polling place: it's private.  That makes vote buying harder, too.

One other ignored factor is hacking of voting machines and tabulation software.  Imagine that the hacking was in the tabulations:  Imagine software that detected that the actual numbers gave the hackers' choice less electoral votes than he needed, then figured out which states could change that result, and added a few more votes, 5, say, to his total in every precinct.  (Would such a minor discrepancy in precinct numbers be noticed?) For example, Pennsylvania had about 9700 precincts. DJT carried PA by 44K votes which is less than 5 x 9700.  

Are voting machines and tabulation software any more secure this year?

My mother (in South Carolina) was born in 1920, a few months before women won the right to vote, and she wanted very much to vote for Hillary in 2016, but at 96 she wasn't physically able to deal with the voting process. She's in a hospice situation now and can't communicate very well, but last year, when I could still talk to her about politics, she would always groan at Trump's name and say "How did we get HIM?" It's complicated. But we can't let it happen again.

I don't know how many first-time or infrequent female voters are left in the US, but statistically there must still be millions. We often talk about the need to mobilize new voters in order to make progressive change. We mention youth and People of Color, but who thinks about women as an incompletely tapped demographic? Trump drove many women into the streets to protest for the first time and inspired many to run for office. But positive inspiration can be an even greater force. A female candidate could provide the same kind of inspiration that Obama did for first-time African American voters and their allies. Turnout in 2018 shattered records for a midterm. Turnout in 2020 can usher in a new small d democratic wave in this country. Warren spoke to this possibility in the debate and it was to me the wisest and most optimistic statement of the evening. She radiates hope and is  thus the most electable of them all.

Elections depend on many factors -- including gender.  Digging up dirt has proved to be effective, for example.  Dukakis had his Willie Horton; Kerry had his swift boat.  So Hilary not only faced gender bias,  but faced the Comey statements about her emails (twice, no less), Benghazi, and the Russian electoral attack, among other issues. And she still beat Trump in the popular vote by 3 million!  If anything, Hillary showed that  a woman can  win.  Yet Trump was able to beat Hillary  in spite of obvious ethical and moral flaws in his background. The Access Hollywood tapes stand out in my mind because the public factored them out.  This is where the gender bias is most evident. Had a  woman been caught in a scandal as Trump was, that would have been a campaign show stopper.  The message for women for the near future is that they are surely electable, and can beat a male opponent but they are held to a higher standard to overcome the gender bias that remains today.  Fifty years ago, they were probably not electable. Fifty years from now, the playing field should be level. At least one hopes so.

I love you too, Gail. You make me laugh when reality only makes me want to cry, or scream. We need unity, not discord to beat Trump. I don’t know whom to believe, but Warren’s display makes me question her political smarts. Dems have to be smart to win in 2020. Remember the Repubs are not constrained by ethics, nor propriety. This is a gang fight. We stick together, or we (all) lose.

Just a arithmetical point. Bernie defeated a Republican in  November 1990, and 30 years would be November 2020, Bernie campaigned for Warren in 2018, and probably in 2012. In 2015, when Warren was being encouraged to run, Sanders urged her run. He also urged Gabbard to run this year.
  What is more relevant? Having  a women as President or having political positions that supported a livable minimum wage years before it became dogma within the Democrat Party. Not having a livable wage is more predominant in the
female workforce than male. Likewise, among other things, who is deprived more from woefully lacking Social Security  benefits= female or male.
  This whole made for CNN event is saddening, and why is CNN with its multi millionaire news celebrities chosen to moderate the debates?
Being "utterly unfit for office" clearly did not disqualify the current incumbent.

Considering that Hillary Clinton had that same perfect record as Warren, i.e., winning two Senate elections in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, the comment during the debate doesn't provide much support that this proves anything about Warren's chances in the general election.   And, Sanders has done pretty well since he finally got elected.  In fact, Sanders has served in Congress longer than any major party candidate in the history of the country. And I don't recall Biden losing except for when he ran for the presidential nomination so I wonder if Warren loses a caucus or primary she will consider herself as a loser, too.

It was simply an inane talking point that has nothing to do with any real issues.

If Elizabeth Warren wins the nomination she will go on to lose the election, not because of gender bias, but because she reminds too many people of the math teacher who flunked them in the tenth grade. People just don’t get over that.

Yes, I'm a guy Gail, but I saw that exchange with Warren and Sanders as a definitive take-down of Warren's assertion that Bernie, of all people, said a woman could not be elected president of the United States.

Yet, the logic of his rebuttal to the charge seemed to just sail off into the ether. And Abby Phillip behaved as if she didn't hear a word Bernie said.

Warren did. And she moved the discussion into a useful direction but I don't much care for the way she got there, any more than I thought Kamala's Harris's attack on Biden for forced busing was the most useful way to approach race.

I'm sorry but I am now convinced Warren would be a poor choice. Not due to her gender but because of how she handles stress. 

When pressed by Trump's tweets and offensive Pocahantas nickname, she took a DNA test. When falling behind in Iowa she didn't just go after the Sanders campaign for playing hardball, but she left us with this choice: either she or Sanders is lying and it's simply difficult to believe her in this instance.

Cheese Louise, Gail, your expectations are not in sync with the current averages of Americans who can name our form of government, the meaning of CIA, what a deficit means in a government context, where is Valley Forge and why should we care, etc. And for what it’s worth, the last thing I want right now in our politics is a revolution or extreme change executed at a time of public mistrust in all government institutions.  Stabilize, heal, national PTSD therapy....THEN bring on the blue sky aspirations and engineer our future to realize at least some of these aspirations while passing others on for another generation to challenge.

There are many reasons, including some that Collins notes, why HRC lost. To which she adds the people-didn't-want-another-two-eight-term-player. 

Let me add another one: There are nearly 40% Americans who are afraid of immigrants, blacks, Jews, Catholics, and how-can-I-forget those Muslims.

Any candidate who has a softer view on these issues is anathema to that segment. It will be yet another decade or two before the last one of them leaves to his/her eternal abode before those issues stop being important ones. 

But until then, progressives have only one path to winning elections: come out and vote in large numbers, especially in the swing states.

Yes, 'we've still got Donald Trump.'

Which makes me think of Franklin Graham's message to the listeners in 2016, 'Just hold your nose and vote.'

'We've still got Donald Trump.'  

Yes we do.

And maybe this should be the new rallying cry for his defeat.

"But we can’t spend the day bewailing the existence of the Electoral College."  Why are we leaving aside discussion of the electoral college as if there's nothing any of us can do about it and such discussion has nowhere to go?  The facts:  The National Popular Vote Bill is three quarters of the way to becoming law, a law stating that all electoral votes will be given to the winner of the national popular vote, with no input needed from the federal government to bring this about.  State legislatures with 196 electoral votes have already signed on and states with 74 more electoral votes are needed. The bill has been partially passed by at least one legislative chamber in 8 states possessing 75 electoral votes (AR, AZ, ME, MI, MN, NC, NV, OK) and has been unanimously approved at the committee level in 2 states possessing 27 more electoral votes (GA, MO).   We are actually so close to one person, one vote, that, with more publicity and social pressure on these state legislatures, we could be free of the electoral college tomorrow--and that's worth talking about.

Ms. Collins should add a couple of hohos to the brilliant analysis in her second paragraph.

You know who told us there's sexism in politics? TIME magazine, whose actions spoke louder than any words could. It didn't put Speaker Pelosi on its cover when she became the first woman to lead a party in Congress. Nor when her first speakership made her the most powerful woman in U.S. history. Nor for any of the quotidian reasons a speaker or minority leader might.

No, TIME moseyed around until last year before putting Ms. Pelosi on its cover for the first time. She had to win a second speakership to achieve it (and by then TIME covers were scrawnier in quantity and influence).

I believe Clinton lost because the Democrats had taken the blue collar worker for granted. They stood idly by while Republicans gutted the unions with Right to Work for Nothing. They yawned while workers wages went flat during Reagan. I agreed with Civil Rights and Women's Rights and LGBT Rights but these were a hard pill for average blue collar Joe Six Pack to swallow. What did the Dems give to him in return?

I believe Clinton lost, in part because - for the first time in history - we would have had a "First Husband" in the White House. There was no preparation for what that would actually mean (duties, protocol, etc.) - Clinton never spoke about that aspect. And because the FH would have been hound-dog William Jefferson Clinton, there was a strange, slightly creepy wild-card aspect to it. I don't think people thought about this consciously, but I do think it influenced their hesitation to vote for Hillary. In other words, it was not just "A Woman President" it was also that there would be an FH, and he would be an ex-president.

I'm beginning to understand the impact of positive, meaningful messages for motivating people. According to Wharton business professor Adam Grant, knowing that you contribute to positive, meaningful work increases productivity and motivation. We saw in 2016 that focusing on Trump, even on beating Trump, does not work. Also, a majority of Americans think politics have become too negative, especially with Trump. So a winner (male or female) would avoid what Warren and Sanders did this week––and seek to positively motivate people to vote for them (becoming a part of their positive, meaningful work) through their tone and messages. A Trump cathexis could be fatal.

I will never vote for a candidate who IS either a woman or a man. That’s identity politics. But I am always open to a candidate who HAPPENS TO BE a woman or a man. I skipped from candidate to candidate and came to rest on Klobuchar.  She strikes me as the best of the lot. It’s got nothing to do with her gender, glass ceilings or the fact that it may be time. She’s the most presidential by me. I couldn’t care less whether she favors pink or blue. And anybody who chooses their candidate based won whether they wore a pink hat or a blue hat in the hospital nursery is not very smart if you ask me.

I don't understand why Gail dismisses Hillary's win of the popular vote as not proving anything.  Hillary got more votes than Trump--considerably more--and that conclusively proves a woman can win, just as women have won head-of-government  in many--dare I say--more advanced countries around the world.  if she's the right candidate at the right time--which Hillary wasn't--she just needs to shrewdly play the Electoral College game, which Hillary didn't.

Hillary Clinton lost the electoral vote because of James Comey's letter and the New York Times' harping on it for days. As Nate Silver observed, there was a measurable drop in polling after this, and it was enough to make a difference. Perhaps this time around the media will not engage in false equivalency and bothsiderism to appear fair and balanced. Or perhaps enough voters will ignore media shenanigans and vote for the adult regardless of gender.

This misses the point. Among many other things, this is an election about the role of civility in American life. Whatever Sanders said to Warren in a private conversation, their talk was that- private. Besides indulging a transparent political trick, perpetrated in apparent near-desperation, Warren and her camp have acted in an uncivil way. Unfortunately, it might work because columns like this in the mainstream media - which is scared to death regarding Sanders' agenda and popularity- indirectly honor Warren's incivility by letting a dirty trick seemingly generate an important discussion, and implicitly providing credence to Warren's unfair accusation. Hopefully, however, this will all backfire, and Democratic voters who are confused by the overlap in Warren's and Sanders' agendas will understand that one behaves as a typical politician whereas the other has campaigned twice for the Presidency in a transparent, authentic and honorable way.

Hillary Clinton lost the 2016 election in the 1st 20 minutes of the 1st debate vs. Trump.  While she droned on about some arcane economic theories, Trump zeroed in on manufacturing jobs lost in Michigan, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Wisconsin.  And kept repeating it.  Here's the crucial point: her supporters wouldn't tell her how badly she had lost that debate.  And so she stopped polling in those states 2 weeks before the election.  Why?  Who knows, maybe to keep the money.  Stanley Greenburg, the noted pollster, has called this lapse "electoral malfeasance."  Clinton was exactly the wrong candidate at the time we needed someone with vision and passion.  So now we have Trump.

On Hillary Clinton's loss in November, 2016: Gail Collins suggests people did not vote for her because she had been around so long and they "just wanted a change." Actually, on that mostly happy November day, when it was sunny and mild and many of us were looking ahead to a Clinton presidency -- before it got dark and Ice-Agey and apocalyptic -- , I was looking forward to Hillary's blooming, and showing us new and wonderful things that we had never seen before, once she was no longer a player in a man's White House, but was herself her own president.

Trump is the best evidence that things may be better than 1964, in the early 60s we got the civil rights act, the voting rights act, Medicare, Medicaid, NPR and PBS, but they are certainly not more progressive.   LBJ's domestic achievements make Sanders and Warren look like conservatives.
Ah! Fantastic! Progress in the third decimal place.

Gail -- good column but not even a mention of the other woman on the debate stage? Amy Klobuchar? Remember her?

Klobuchar has more political chops than Warren, she has won three statewide elections in Minnesota (which is turning red outside the Twin Cities).  She and Warren agree on most issues; their differences are on the pace of change and efficacy of their proposals. Klobuchar is more the realist, in that she knows how difficult, if not impossible, it will be to pass Warren's proposals even if the Dems gain control of the Congress. 

The difference was stated clearly by AK at the debate in November, when she commented about Elizabeth: "you're not the only one with good ideas."

That said, I urge commenters to read Warren's and Klobuchar's NY Times interviews all the way through. You will find a degree of comfort and confidence that either one could be a first woman President, and not a moment too soon.

Yes, Gail, we have Donald Trump.  And part of the reason for that is that Hillary received 40 000 fewer votes in Milwaukee County in 2016 than Obama in 2012.  Why?  Because after winning the Wisconsin Democratic primary, she never once again appeared in the state.  Even the mayor of Madison at the time noted that he was not contacted by the Clinton campaign after the state primary.

Hillary lost because she did not work for it.

I voted for her.  Next time I will vote for the candidate that bothers to show up in my state.  Other than the present WH occupant.

There is a clear path for women to gain equality in the worlds of employment and politics: Commit themselves to earning 1/2 of the family income, and allow men to earn no more than the other half.  That is not what we have now.  What we have now, according to the Pew survey of 2017, is 70% of men in straight relationships earning all or most of the family income.  More striking, other surveys have revealed that the EXPECTATION that men will be the sole or primary earner is even higher than 70% among straight women, and higher still among upper middle class women.  As long as men are expected to be the sole or primary earner, as long as boys are raised with the expectation they WILL be earners, while girls are raised with an understanding they MIGHT be earners, women will not be considered equally committed to the workplace.  How many men do you know who are asked "Will you continue to work when the baby comes?"  None.  Because men are not given such a choice.  Their reward? Long hours in a cubicle, shortened life spans, and little time for parenting.  The ridiculous narrative that women have been denied opportunities to work equally are just that: ridiculous.  How many men might prefer to work less and parent more?  Plenty.  If women want equality in employment and politics, the answer is clear: Stop considering financial dependence on men a status option, assume you are equally responsible for earning, assume men are equally responsible for parenting, and parity will occur.

The two incredible persons named Elizabeth and Amy should be a source of pride for the Democratic Party and the USA. We've got to stop handicapping the race as if we are looking for a sure thing. If we truly believe in the ideas, the content and the policy - nothing else should matter- particularly gender. One can go blind trying to see with eyes other than our own.   Guessing at what that voter in Pennsylvania is thinking is a sad way to celebrate citizenship, so let those with an appetite for power alone consume themselves. The trap of finding electability speaks to an insecurity that our friends at fox have cultivated to unsettle the proud culture of public service for the common good. May we search the candidates soul for the ideals for which we fought , stay true to them-  and honor will follow .

It’s a little ironic that the imbroglio Warren launched this week and fed last night could serve to lose her the good will of the Bernie Bros, and diminish her chance to be the first female president. But hey, better to be right than victorious.

Gail, my mom gave me your book “When Everything Changed” a few years back. It was a startling read, as it drove home how very recent and fragile are the battles and wins for women’s rights. Mom has always been prescient, and I think she saw this Trump backlash brewing at the same time I was confident we were soon to have our first woman president. Don't take anything for granted, sisters! I hope this time, my much more shaky confidence might be borne out.
We’ve come a long way! But we still have a long way to go.

The future belongs to women. With in vitro fertilization we will become unneeded except to mow the lawn and change a tire – though it won't be long before robots do the mowing and tires become obsolete. Like men.

Well, there's no forgetting Donald Trump. He's made himself the #1 issue on the ballot. That means defeating him in the Electoral College, where he has a distinct advantage. 

Polls in the battleground states show Biden and Sanders have the best chance of beating there. A female can certainly be President, but Warren and Klobuchar are just not the strongest candidates to win this year.

I read almost the entire (2 hour) transcript of Warren's interview with the Times.  She is stunningly well-studied in EVERYTHING.  She knows how laws work.  She knows how industries work.  She is dazzlingly smart.  I was so glad to see her have a strong night.  I think she's got my vote in the primary.

I love you, Gail.  I love your total grasp of history, and your amazing ability to laugh at it in spite of it.  Thank you for this column, and for all your wonderful books that have given us insight into the role of women in this great nation.  We WILL overcome, and I appreciate your helping us laugh while working toward it.

Sometimes for a woman to succeed in business or politics, she has to be just like a man, aggressive, unsympathetic, and forget about being emotionally intelligent. In other words, they could not display the characteristics of femininity that makes for a good mother or someone who thinks about peaceful solutions to problems. I'd like to think that's changing, however. 

Elizabeth Warren seems motivated by wanting to make things better for everyone--economically, socially, politically. Further, she has spent decades researching the problems that make life difficult for individuals and families and coming up with solutions that will actually make things better. Too many men, especially Republican men have made things worse in this country. Donald Trump in only three years has made it to the top of that list, but it also includes among others W. Bush and Ronald Reagan. 

So for myself, the person who moves me and makes me want to contribute to her campaign and work for her success is Elizabeth Warren. And it seems this is true for others as well. I'm glad to see it. Perhaps there is hope for this country. Now let's also win the senate and especially see the defeat of Mitch McConnell by another woman, Amy McGrath.

Impossible. I wish I could but the future of my grandchildren has already been gravely threatened. Unless the primary threat is removed, they and their entire generation around the world will face egregious challenges, to say the least. 
It is for a future of possibility, not one of conflict and disaster, that recent descent into chaos must be reversed. Now.

Many of Amy Klobuchar’s staff left because she was a difficult woman.  She even admitted that she had had some problems.  Hillary Clinton lost because people did not like her.  She had a personality problem.   Elizabeth Warren seems nice enough but is too progressive for most Americans.  Women are certainly qualified to be in politics but we need the right kind of women.  We should look at the total candidate before we vote and not their gender.

I would be happy to vote for Elizabeth Warren.  She could be a fantastic president.
But I’m not pleased with the way she is casting herself as aggrieved by Bernie Sanders.
The scripted call by the Sanders campaign, which describes Warren’s supporters as being too exclusive a group to win, may or may not prove correct.  However, it was not badmouthing and it was not dirty politics.  The offense she expresses is disproportionate to what happened.
Then there is the he said/she said narrative about whether Sanders told her, in 2018, that a woman can’t win.  If he really said that, and if she really took umbrage at him, why did she wait until now to say it?  The timing with his surge in Iowa seems more than a little coincidental.
And Warren’s pointed refusal to shake hands with Sanders at Wednesday’s debate looked flat out petty.
This woman believes that a woman candidate can beat Trump this year.  But to do so, she can’t keep presenting herself as a victim.  You can be sure that Trump is going to be a lot more vicious than any man running in the Democratic primaries.

"I’ve always suspected that Clinton lost — to the degree that she lost — not so much because of her gender as because people just wanted a change. "

I have friends who have gone through a midlife crisis. I've gone through a midlife crisis. Twice. The 2016 election was not a midlife crisis.

Electing Donald Trump was much closer to a terrible twos temper tantrum. At least if two year olds were racist. And forced to watch Hannity instead of more mature television. 

Polls indicate that about 40% of Americans still refuse to grow up and act like responsible citizens preferring to cheer on the child in the White House as he breaks everything in sight. 

That still leaves enough Americans to put an adult in the White House in 2020. ALL the top Democratic candidates are adults. The top three poll leaders have been actual fully functioning adults for over fifty years. I'm going to go with that being a good thing. 

Any of them will have my enthusiastic vote. But if Americans really do insist on something different, a woman would be a nice change from the little spoiled boy we have now. Or maybe just someone who believes in Democracy. And reading.

Amy Klobuchar is a highly electable woman for President. 

If we nominate Warren we will almost certainly get an unhappy sequel to 2016.

I voted for Clinton, but dislike her intently.  Not because she's a woman, but because due to her personality.  She exhibited a smug air of entitlement about the presidency.  Even the 'I'm with her' slogan bypassed our country completely.

That being said, I'd be delighted to vote for a woman again.  But I won't do it just because of her gender.  She'll have to be terrific presidential material.  Or running against Trump.

The calculus of electability; the incumbent advantage; Russian meddling; the counter-democratic electoral college; the hail Mary of declaring war.  
Honestly, analysis of reasoned debate isn’t fruitful this time around.   Better that we of good will just throw money at anyone in the party who knows how to exploit media.  This is no way going to be a fair election.

I wish the moderators had asked Warren about her longtime working relationship with Sanders, as it relates to what she said he said.   Ie, was the statement in keeping with what she has witnessed over the years. 

It would have shed some light on the allegation.

I don't believe Hillary Clinton lost because she is a woman. HRC has a history of bad luck, her husbands moral failures, Bengazi, the email debacle following that, umpity weeks of Republican hearings, and Comey.

If either Elizabeth Warren or Amy Klochubar gets the nomination, their chances of winning are every bit as good as Sanders, Biden, or Buttigieg.

Down deep I want one of those two women to take on Trump and win. It would truly place America back where it belongs.  A nation of immigrants and freedom for all who enter.

We have had many good Democratic presidential candidates in recent decades.  We had Mondale, and we had Dukakis, and we had Gore, and we had Kerry, and we had Hillary Clinton.  Since they all lost, none of their policies could be implemented at the time.

We must consider electability when we cast our ballots.  We cannot throw away our votes on candidates who realistically have no chance of winning.

I don't know about you, but I feel as though I've aged 30 years in the past three years.  I really can't afford that.  It sure seems like 2016 was a really bad year for America.  We have to do better in 2020.

I don't care if he said it or not. If Warren is telling the truth she made no mention of Sanders saying it in a way that puts down women. She didn't accuse him of saying a woman was incapable of being president. 

The fact that she would throw a friend under the bus just to get a news cycle on her terms sounds just as pathetic as Trump. I will say in her defense I don't think she outright lied. The question is why?

I have definitely given up on her as a presidential candidate after this one.

How can Sanders not see that this whole spat is counterproductive to her campaign? All it does is sow negativity which will not accrue to her benefit. Who really cares what he might have said in a side conversation a long time ago. Ensnaring herself in this demonstrates more of a sign of weakness on her part.

If Warren wins the nomination by pushing gender issues I won't vote for her. Gender issues are important but it is destructive to use them to distract us from the class struggle, which is much more important. It is stupid to spend much energy squabbling over how to divide a rapidly shrinking slice of pie.

"You called me a liar on national TV".  This sounds scripted to me - spoken at a time and place that was intended to be picked up and go viral.  I could be wrong of course but it looked to me like Warren set up Bernie (I am an undecided voter).  Bernie reacted with shock and some dignity - this is not the place.  I give Bernie credit for walking away.  Frankly, men have had 2000+ years to prove they can improve society and have screwed it up consistently.  It's time to give women a chance all across the power spectrum.  Wall Street would be a good place to start.

I don't believe for a second that Warren thinks Sanders is sexist, or else their "friendship" would not have survived.

The fact that she did not quash this leak, and appears to have scripted exactly how she wanted it to go does not help to dissipate the feeling that the conversation we are having is very much on purpose, including the refusal to shake his hand on live TV. If she somehow didn't realize this (unlikely for a very smart person like her), then I would question her temperament and judgment.

I don't know who started it all. Warren obviously misunderstood something Bernie said.  Humans mispeak, misunderstand, and make mistakes.  I was struck that neither of them seems ready to quickly heal this rift.  They need a meeting and. a joint press conference to explain.  
And then, please, move on.  For people to use this tiny fraction of a misunderstanding to make decisions about voting is ludicrous.  Both candidates are very authentic, hard working, smart and credible.  And honest.  Two honest people can remember things differently.   They are not evil, sly, or stubborn because of that.  Bernie defended himself well, and Warren let it go and used the moment to her benefit.  The press blew this way out of proportion.   Try to focus, folks, on what matters!

Here's what I think about this nonsensical topic when the entire country is going off the rails:  If a candidate has a compelling message for the voters and can transmit a positive vision for returning the US to rule of law and making life better for all its citizens, it will not matter their sex, sexuality, race, ethnic origins, none of it. What we have here are two inferior candidates that can only light their respective bases on fire, and neither one is catching on with the vast majority of Americans who want a positive vision for our future, or just an end to the nightmare we are living.

Frankly I am going to support both Sanders and Warren and am not in the least interested in this spat.  There is absolutely nothing new or news worthy about this issue and I consider it an entirely media manufactured nothing burger. 

Everyone understands both sexism and the gender issues around the election of the first female POTUS. That issue has little to do with either of these candidates.  What I want to see is both of them work to defeat Biden, Buttigieg  and especially the billionaires.

Bernie and Elizabeth, please go to lunch, issue a joint statement of mutual agreement and respect, shake hands (!),and get this story out of the media. To perpetuate this childish schoolyard spat only undermines both your candidacies. And to sacrifice the real possibility of a truly progressive administration for the first time in over 80 years over this would be unforgivable. (That's the message you should be giving your more undisciplined supporters too).

I support both Sanders and Warren, but for the life of me I can't fathom a single good reason why Warren's camp would leak that conversation, no matter whether he said it or not.

I mean, we are not talking about amateur hour high school student council candidates here - these are United States Presidential candidates.  What possible strategy was behind the leak?  Nothing makes sense.

Set aside the he said / she said controversy for a moment; also ignore whether or not there is sexism among some voters against ambitious female politicians.

I am very concerned about the “Bernie Bro” e-coomunity culture (for the lack of the better word) and its bullying, harassing and sexist online and social media behavior. I am concerned with Bernie ability to ignore, or pretend to not be aware of, what’s happening in his name in the online world. This is not even limited to a bunch of over-excited young wannabe communists but extend to more established thought leaders in that world, such as Nathan Robinson from The Jacobin. Bernie might be coming across as your friend you want to have a beer with, but underneath, there is the same intransigence and intolerance than back in 1793 France or 1918 Bolshevik Russia. Second, there is a great big race between the Chinese Communist  Party and the Chinese Civil Society. The big question is: can the CCP evolve and grow its capacity to manage the Chinese population as that population becomes wealthier, more educated, and more global and cosmopolitan?  How long will ordinary Chinese citizens tolerate their inability to choose the leaders of their government when they make free choices in other parts of their lives?

I think the author asks the wrong questions: how can we stay ahead of China as a great power, how can we better compete with China, how can we keep China from "closing the gap."

In my opinion, the right question is how can we better cooperate with China to improve the lives of American and Chinese people.

On a personal level, I buy products from both countries. For example, I recently designed and installed an LED lighting system for my apartment's master bedroom that makes it appear as bright as day when the lights are on (200 watts). Some of the components are American and some are Chinese. American companies and workers benefited, Chinese companies and workers benefited, and I really enjoy being in the bedroom because it is the best lit room in my apartment.

America should also confront China to discourage it from cheating (for example to end the theft of intellectual property and state support of industries that put American companies out of business). Some of these goals require tough negotiations where the reward is continued cooperation.

What should the US do in response to China's rise? That is the question for us. Do we engage in another arms race, only to end up the same way the last one did, or worse (the Thucydidean trap)? Do we let all the brakes off our economy, and compete with China in the degradation of the Earth? Must we compete at all?

I think it's interesting that the answer to the first question would be a response that would also be a necessary precondition for either an arms race or a radically deregulated economy. We have to get our house in order. We have to recommit to the ongoing democratic experiment that defines what America is better than anything else. The situation today eerily resembles that foreseen by Lincoln, where he warned that the greatest threat to the country's survival wouldn't come from the outside, but from internal divisions. 

Corruption becomes dangerous not when it simply occurs, but when it becomes accepted. This to me is as disturbing as anything, what seems a growing acceptance of gross and obvious corruption at the highest levels, whence it naturally flows downward in both business and politics.

The best US response to China's rise is what it always has been: To restore and rebuild the corrupt foundations of our own house.

I am not a lawyer, but the issue of standing is, at the basics, easily understood. The second principle relating to standing is actual harm.  Courts have a terrible problem with potential harm, so many current issues are left unresolved or actively discarded because the bad news has yet to strike.  Among the reasons for creation of law, rules and regulations, there are the classes that I call (a) rules to allow social order and (b) rules to prevent harm.  Examples include federal regulations about how to split up the broadcast spectrum of frequencies for (a) and regulations for management of research on dangerous things, such as viruses, for (b).  Although one can comment on laws and regulations through testimony and through the Federal Register, once these rules are in place, it is hard to sue to remove or revise regulations until the rules themselves have caused a problem.  The issue is establishing standing.  In the case of abortion clinics, it comes back to the fact that we need to prove that the rules caused clinics to close, not just that there was the potential to cause closure.  We physicians know that the rules requiring hospital privileges are a sham, but it is hard to prove, hence the lawsuit in Louisiana.

The issue of standing, while usually in the background, has always been an important factor, and far from being apolitical.
